passages.text: August 28, 2025 01:00 AM GMT
Cooper Companies Inc (COO.O) Price Target
Weakens our thesis Impact to our thesis
Modest shortfall Financial results versus consensus
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research
F3Q org sales growth of \(+2\%\) was below Cons \((+5.9\%)\) and buyside expectations with both segments missing.
CVI shortfalls driven by declines in Clariti due to potential cannibalization from MyDay.
CSI weakness attributable to slowdowns in the equipment purchasing environment.
Despite the FY25 sales guide cut, COO remains optimistic about 2026, where it thinks growth can accelerate.
Our PT moves to \(\) 76\(from\) \ \(84\) .Remain EW.

COO in a tough spot: COO very clearly had a difficult Q3 print, with CVI organic growth of \(+2\%\) well shy of buyside expectations of \(+5\%\) . Candidly, the explanation on the call of MyDay strength cannibalizing Clariti is a little confusing given the different parts of the price piano these products play in, and big picture it begins to feel like each quarter is presenting with a different heterogenous explanation for slowing growth. It's particularly perplexing given the relative strength of peers (e.g. ALC Contacts \(+7\%\) , J&J \(3\%\) , BLCO \(+7\%\) ), and indeed, BLCO actually added the same dollar \((\) 16mn) value- it's contact business in the quarter as COO (despite being a fraction of the size). This (plus challenges in CSI) have left COO in a tricky spot despite the stock having derated significantly over the last year, and we're still very much in a \(3\) - bw- me situation. There were encouraging elements - despite pricing sounding softer in 2026 (maybe \(+1 - 2\%\) industry wide vs. \(+2 - 3\%\) prior) COO is committing to taking share, and the explanation for how the management team knew it was Clariti being hit by MyDay was compelling (few larger accounts that they directly called). OPEX management has also been excellent. Still, we think trust is going to take time to rebuild. We keep wanting to get more positive on COO shares, but keep running into reasons to remain on the sidelines, and need to see some stability in the decline of the growth to get comfortable, while wondering if larger strategic changes at the corporate- level could potentially end up being on the table given the relative performance versus history.
MORGAN STANLEY & CO.LLC Patrick A. Wood, CFA
Justin X Wang Research Associate
Cooper Companies Inc (COO.O, COO US)
Medical Technology | United States of America
Shr price, close (Aug 27, 2025)
Unless otherwise noted, all metrics are based on Morgan Stanley ModelWare
\(^{**}\) = Based on consensus methodology
\(^{**}\) = Based on consensus methodology
\(^{**}\) = Morgan Stanley Research estimates
\(e =\) Morgan Stanley Research estimates, a = Actual Company reported data

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

Key Takes from the Call: 1) Early 2026 Thoughts: While COO did not provide concrete details, it expects an acceleration in growth within both segments. For CVI, the company expects to exceed market growth of +MSD on the backs of stronger fitting volumes and launches in OUS geographies. That said, management acknowledged that price taking could be lower for contact lenses due to pressures in APAC (+1% in 2026 vs. +2- 3% historically). For CSI, management expects growth to be driven by fertility, where positive secular trends like delayed childbirth, patient awareness, and broader payer coverage remain intact. With that said, the segment continues to experience a slower capital purchasing environment as practices aim to conserve cash given the macro backdrop. 2) MyDay Greenshoots: A bright spot in the quarter was the MyDay family, where all lines grew +DD in F3Q with MyDay Multifocals up +20%. COO highlighted that fitting activity is strong and implies a growth ramp nearer term. Furthermore, the company shared that it has renewed several large contracts and won multiple private label agreements. Bolstering growth, MyDay Multifocal is expected to launch commercially in major APAC markets with the MyDay Toric parameter already actively rolled out in multiple markets. Finally, Cooper emphasized that with the completion of the latest CapEx cycle, it has significantly expanded MyDay capacity, as it expects to handle continued growth in the product. During the call, management disclosed that MyDay represents around \(\) 600M\(in annual sales, which compares to\) \ \(400M\) in Clariti (total \(\) 1B\(in daily silicone hydrogel). That said, it noted during the call that MyDay's margins are not as attractive as other products (e.g. Clariti), which we think could affect earnings power in 2026.

F3Q topline weaker, but profitability ahead: COO's F3Q print was worse than most expected with lower sales of \(\) 1,060m\((Street at\) \ \(1,064m\) ) representing slower \(+2\%\) group organic growth (vs. \(+4.9\%\) Cons). Gross profit was also behind at \(\) 713m\(vs.\) \ \(715m\) ) though adj. was EBIT slightly better at \(\) 276m\(vs.\) \ \(275m\) Cons), resulting in a \(3\%\) EPS beat ( \(\) 1.10\(vs.\) \ \(1.07\) Cons). CVI growth was weaker than expected (+2% Organic vs. \(+5.9\%\) Cons), with shortfalls in both segments (Toric & Multifocals at \(+6\%\) vs. \(+7\%\) Cons and Spheres at - 1% vs. \(+4.9\%\) Cons). This compares to Alcon's C2Q print of \(+7\%\) CC, though we acknowledge different prior year comps and calendar dynamics. CSI was similarly weaker than what the street anticipated at \(+2\%\) organic (vs. \(+2.6\%\) Cons) with Office and Surgical softer (+1% vs. \(+2.6\%\) Cons) and Fertility also lagging (+3% vs. \(+4.1\%\) Cons). For FY25 guidance, COO cut group organic sales growth targets to \(+4.4.5\%\) from \(+5.6\%\) (vs. \(+5.7\%\) Street), predicted on lower CVI organic growth of \(+4.5\%\) (vs. \(+6.0.7\%\) prior and \(+6.5\%\) Cons) and CSI organic growth of \(+3.3.5\%\) (vs. \(+3.5.4.5\%\) prior and \(+3.9\%\) Cons). Allin, COO now expects FY25 adj. EPS of \(\) 4.08\(-\) 4.12 (vs.\) \ \(4.05\) - \(\) 4.11\(prior and\) \ \(4.07\) Cons), implying a 4Q EPS of \(\) 1.10\(-\) 1.14 (vs.\) \ \(1.12\) Cons).

Model Update: We are adjusting our model for the print, contemplating in the softness within both the contacts and fertility markets. As such, our organic growth expectations move to \(+4.1\% / + 5.0\%\) (from \(+5.4\% / + 6.3\%\) ) and our EPS expectations move to \(\) 4.10/\(\) 4.42\(from\) \ \(3.98/\) \ \(4.56\) . Accordingly, we are lowering our price target to \(\) 76\(from\) \ \(84\) ) based on lower growth expectations and reduced visibility into end- market demand.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
